Ok [[user_first_name]]. Let's start adding accounts.
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Checking' and then enter the current balance of that account. 

Feel free to give your accounts creative names. (e.g. On it's last leg, Gone soon, etc)

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Select + Add Account!
I'M BACK!

For this step, you'll need to log into your bank and see the current balance. Come back when you're ready with that information!

<<Accounts>>

Do you have credit cards that you use to make purchases regularly? (Yes/No)
I'm Done

<<Accounts>>

Now Click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select "Credit Card' as the type of account and then enter the current balance of that account. 

If you have more credit cards simply repeat this step for each card you spend on regularly.

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Ok Let's Do It! Select + Add Account!
I'm Ready

<<Accounts>>

For this step, you'll need to log in to your credit card account(s) to see the current balance(s). 

The best way to track your spending is to create an account for each credit card. Come back when you've got all that information!

YES
credit_cards = yes
move_to: add_account
Budget Summary Overview

Now let's meet your new best friend. Yes, I know I'm your bestie, but I'm willing to share. Only because it's so you can live your best life. 
 
This is where you will be coming to share everything you did with your money. 

 Please click on the Budget button.

<<Budget>>

I'll give you a tour of your budget screen. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.

<<Budget>>

For example, if you want to compare several months at once.

 Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
move_to: budget_header
Sounds Good

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount.


 There are multiple ways to move money around your budget.

 Remember that your budget is flexible!

<<Budget>>

Moving Right Along, you're rocking it!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget your dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get to work on these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. 

If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category; that's called a deficit. 

If the amount is black, that's what you have available. That's called a surplus.

<<Budget>>

The reality is, if you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.


 Thus begins a vicious cycle!!!!

<<Budget>>

Select the three dots to the left of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table. 

This gives you visual options. 

You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category-Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. The rows in 'Grey' that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.'

The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your cell phone.

<<Budget>>

Nice [[user_first_name]]! You're getting pretty good at this.
Add Transaction

<<Accounts>>

Quick Note: 

For checking account transactions, PAYMENTS added will DECREASE the balance and any DEPOSITS added will  INCREASE the balance.

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.
move_to: add_new_button

For the category, select "Bills."

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance is minus $100.

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete this fake transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Just like that, you're on your way to achieving financial stability. I'm loving the momentum.  Let's Keep it Going!!!

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Here's what's next!

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...

Budget Skills

Whew [[user_first_name]]! 
Guess What?!?!?!

You Made it! I'm so proud of you. It is never a mistake when you continue to show up for yourself.
Always remember if you get stuck or need help. Please feel free to book a call with me.

If you have a burning question feel free to email me at nia@perspectiveschange.com
Subject : MBC
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/cbc-schittscreek-schitts-creek-3h4Bo5fja4ZgYS0WEg

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.
I'm ready!

Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is unique budgeting software that includes a virtual avatar.

You selected me, Nia, as your new financial bff. Together, we'll work together to help you reach your goals. 

Let's Get Started!

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Monthly Bills
create_category: Monthly Bills: 🏠 Rent/Mortgage (1st)
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!

<<Budget>>

See! You can make a budget based on your lifestyle!

<<Budget>>

As you add more transactions and payments, your budget table will update automatically. 
When you click NEXT the sample budget table will be deleted and you will have the opportunity to create your own budget table. 

Add each of the categories to reflect your personal budget. 

Some sample categories are Utility bills, food delivery apps, etc.

<<Budget>>

Wrap-up setup

<<Budget>>

How to move money

1. Select the To Budget number; 
2. Enter the amount into the Budgeted column; 
3. Select the amount in Balance and choose 
4. Transfer to another category

<<Budget>>

Reminder: You're working off of the money you have. 

For example, don't budget your entire month of housing expenses if you only have ten days left.

<<Budget>>

The Balance column shows how your balance adjusts after allocating funds to each category. Remember, if this balance is red, you are spending more money than your income can keep up with. 

In this case, we work to alleviate that by making cuts to eliminate that deficit.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
This is the end of the introduction conversation. A user can reset the conversation under the Manage Coach section.

<<Budget>>

When making your budget, consider your next pay date and start with any bills due between now and the next time you get paid. 

Fill those in with the amounts needed.  

Don't forget to add other misc. expenses like copays, hair, nails, haircuts, salons, or school fees.

<<Budget>>

Now, you would put money into the categories for regular things, like gasoline for your car. 
Not only those but similar bills that are recurring. Put money in all of these—not for the whole month's worth, just until you get paid again.

<<Budget>>

Quick Question: Did you budget all your money to zero? If not, could you go ahead and assign those extra funds? 

If you’ve gone negative, make some executive decisions by adjusting any extra funds so they are back to zero.
No, I'm not budgeting with a partner

<<Accounts>>

I was born and raised in Chicago, but I moved to ATL in Oct 2023. I'm the single mother of a 23 year old.

More importantly, I wasn't always good with money but now that I am... I'm going to help you.   Can I ask if you're budgeting with a partner?

<<Accounts>>

Understood! Let's Keep it Moving

<<Accounts>>

Ok great! Please share with me their first name.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for sharing [[user_first_name]]. I look forward to working with you and [[partner_name]].

<<Accounts>>

Great job! Let's move on to adding a transaction.

What kind of device?

Consider asking a user what type of device they are using. If using a computer, the current language for how to access options works. If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). Can utilize the IF syntax to adjust the response in a box where overviewing how to use software dependent on the device the user has.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.
Additional Conversations
Simple FIN

MyBudgetCoach has a direct import option. A coach can either walk through in detail how to complete this, or they can create a separate conversation for if a user to click through at a later point if interested.

Accounts can be linked at any time, so if added manually, can then link for direct import later on.

Linking direct import immediately can be helpful as SimpleFIN's connection will automatically set the starting balance. But the process takes some time and for a new user, they may want to make progress on the software itself and not spend 10-15 minutes just setting up direct import. 

Could always recommend they delete prior accounts, and add new ones once SimpleFIN is linked. This first budget is just a test to get started. Set up real budget with your actual accounts and setting up.
What's Next???

<<Accounts>>

There are just a few more functions to point out on the Account screen.

<<Accounts>>

The 'Import' button allows you to upload an export of transactions from your bank.
move_to: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category...).
move_to: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.

Please note: These are also available in the Budget screen as well. 

However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
move_to: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
move_to: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

<<Accounts>>

Some of your other options are to:

1. Show running balance
2. Hide 'cleared' checkboxes
3. Export
4. Reconcile
5. Link account
6. Close account
move_to: more_button
Coach can decide how much explanation they want to provide for each of these. Reconciliation for example can be a complex discussion.

<<Accounts>>

For example, Type " Cell Phone Provider" as your Payee.
move_to: select_payee
move_to: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment box.
move_to: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
move_to: cleared_status_icon
move_to: save_transaction
move_to: months_band
move_to: budget_table
move_to: category_column
move_to: budgeted_column
move_to: spent_column
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group row, not shaded grey and not bold text, are called Categories. 

When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.

<<Budget>>

[[user_first_name]], if you look below the categories, you will find the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose after your first month.
move_to: received_column

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears. Selecting this opens up a note box. 

This can be used to capture helpful information about that category. For example, the amount you intend to budget each month or when it is due, if not due monthly.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two now down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.

<<Budget>>

Let's move on to how to go about budgeting your dollars and how to give every dollar a job!

<<Budget>>

I want to take a moment and give you your flowers because you are moving through and understanding how to use the Budget! 

Before we wrap up, there is probably one topic you have been wondering about: Credit Cards??

Let's head over to the account screen to talk through this.
This section could be very extensive, or you could keep it high level and create a separate conversation the next time the user gets paid.

Now is a good time to think about if you plan to pay the full balance, minimum payment, or more than the minimum.

Credit cards are seen as negative balances so that's why they will be shown that way in your budget..

<<Accounts>>

 OK Great! If you want to make a payment on a credit card, the best way to do that would be a transfer transaction. 

You are basically transferring money from your bank account to pay your credit card.

<<Accounts>>

To do that select 'Transfer To / From' in the Payee; no Category; transaction automatically added in other account.

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.
Could ask the user if they have more than one card. Could limit to just one or two they use most frequently.
Could ask the user if they plan to pay off card in-full. If they do, don't need to complete the steps. If they don't, steps are important.
Could ask the user if they see a negative Red Overbudgeted number, or if it is less than they expected.
move_to: selected_transactions_button

It's so nice to e-meet you [[user_first_name]]! I want to celebrate! You're taking the first step toward making better money moves! 


I'm here to help, but I'll start by telling you a little about me and who I am.

If you ever feel stuck or need to talk through it, I'm here to help. Book some time for us to meet. 
I am here to help.
Tell Me More!

I love helping others build confidence in their money moves. I'm not just an avatar;

I'm a real person who loves traveling, listening to music, and trying new foods. 

I will walk you through many of the strategies, I have used on my own financial journey and helped other students achieve their financial goals. 

I also realize that money is only a part of your finances.
I have Budgeted Before
No, This is My First Time

A Few Housekeeping Tips:

If you need to start from the beginning at any time. You have options. Simply click the three vertical dots in the bottom right. One option is: "Reset Conversation." which will clear the current conversation. 

Another option is to select "Manage Coach" and then click "Reset Coach." This resets the introduction conversation and clears out any other conversations.

<<Accounts>>

Secondly, if you need to chat simply send me a message within the Message Center (below the "Manage Coach" button). 

If you are stuck or need to meet with me or get some feedback. Feel free to Schedule a Zoom Call on my calendar.

<<Accounts>>

[[user_first_name]], if you ever need to revisit the last message, simply press the back button. Now Let's get to work.

financial_goal = [user_input]
Let's GOOO

<<Accounts>>

One of the best tips I give my students is to always create a name for your budget based on whatever goal your are working on? 

hmm, I wonder what you will name your budget.

<<Budget>>

The budgeting method we are using is called the envelope method. 

If you're not familiar with it, that's okay.  The envelope is a budgeting method where you create categories, aka envelopes, for each expense in your budget.

<<Budget>>

A deficit means we'll need to work to get that money back in our budget by analyzing our expenses. A surplus means we'll need to allocate those funds to our financial goals.
No, I got This!

<<Budget>>

If you are confused or find yourself a little lost in the process, don't hesitate to hit the back button and review again carefully. 

Also I'm always here to help so Schedule a Zoom call if you need me to work with it with you.

<<Accounts>>

First I'll teach you some of the basic features and how to navigate the program. I want to make sure you are familiar with the system first. 


Once you've got the hang of that we'll make your budget with real numbers and I'll walk you through those steps.

Now, let's go back to your budget and add categories for each of your credit cards.
(select Budget to the left to continue).
Yikes, it definitely is Red
Nope Everything Looks Good

<<Budget>>

If you see a Red overbudgeted number before you have covered your bills, that’s important information.  

It means you might have to get creative until you’re paid again. If this happens often, it might be a sign that your expenses are higher than your income. 

This is a good thing to find out because now you can do something about it.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate to Accounts to continue our conversation (select an account to the left to continue).
move_to: account

<<Accounts>>

Now that we got that out of the way.  I have a question.

<<Accounts>>

Ok great! Let's Keep Moving [[user_first_name]].

<<Accounts>>

 OK Good to Know. Here's a Breakdown of budgeting. 

A Budget is simply a Plan for your money. It's a window into your wallet. 

The purpose is to display all the money coming in and out of your wallet in one place. 

One of the first steps is knowing what your financial goals are so you know why you are doing this. 

Then the budgets job is to let you know what extra money you have available in your current budget so you can find a goal for it to tackle.
Let's GOOOOO

<<Accounts>>

Now that we have a better understanding of what budgeting is ... Let's keep moving.

<<Budget>>


Be sure to add all of the expenses that reflect your monthly bills. This will ensure that you are capturing them all.

 Protip: Review your monthly statement to make sure you don't forget any expenses. 

Come back when you've completed your full budget.
Let's Go

<<Accounts>>

Before we continue. We need to update your accounts to reflect the categories on your credit cards to your newly created categories.  

Click on your transaction " Starting Balance" and categorize that transaction to the appropriate credit card account.  

Let's go back to your budget to figure out how you are going to pay off your credit cards.
GOT IT!

<<Accounts>>

Reconcile means to make sure you're budgeting the right amount of dollars! 

Check your bank account regularly and add transactions. 

This helps MyBudgetCoach match your bank account and helps you to trust your numbers.

<<Budget>>

Don't worry. That's why you are here. We are here to help you take control of your finances, and you have made some pretty big steps today.  Think about what changes can be made by your next paycheck.  Remember you can always send me a message or set up a call. I'm here to help.

<<Budget>>

Great! That Sounds like we are making great progress. Determine what goals those extra funds can be allocated towards.
I'm Done
Let me know when you have added your credit card categories.
How Do I Do That?

<<Budget>>

 
If you don't choose to pay the full balance on your credit cards. You can rollover your overspending.

<<Budget>>

Simply choose the balance column in your credit card categories. (the negative red number). 

Then select the option rollover over spending. 

Remember you have the option to not pay your full credit card balance and rollover that money to be used to stay afloat. Press the back button to those instructions if necessary.

<<Budget>>

After you complete this action it will be reflected in your To Budget. 

 Now it time to decide what goal will this money be used for?
